perturbation.original_text: 6.5 Trade Names. The Company shall not create or use any corporate or trade names that include the Arizona Licensed Trademarks, other than those in existence immediately prior to the Effective Date. No later than thirty (30) days following the Closing, each of AWP and the Company shall change its respective corporate name and trade name and cause its organizational documents to be amended to remove any reference to "Armstrong."
perturbation.changed_text: 6.5 Trade Names. The Company shall not create or use any corporate or trade names that include the Arizona Licensed Trademarks, other than those in existence immediately prior to the Effective Date. Each of AWP and the Company shall change its respective corporate name and trade name and cause its organizational documents to be amended to remove any reference to "Armstrong" no later than one hundred and eighty (180) days following the Closing.
perturbation.explanation: The original contract stipulated a 30-day period for changing corporate names to remove references to "Armstrong." However, modifying this to 180 days could contradict Delaware's General Corporation Law, which mandates timely updates to reflect changes in corporate names to avoid misrepresentation and ensure accuracy in legal filings and business operations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Delaware General Corporation Law ยง 102(a)(1) (corporate name requirements and amendments)

perturbation.original_text: 6.6 With respect to any Trademarks notified to the Company in writing after the Effective Date that are used as of the Effective Date in the Company Field and are not (i) owned by any Company Entity, (ii) Arizona Assigned Trademarks, or (iii) Seller Licensed Trademarks (the "Phase-Out Marks") in each case (i)-(iii) the Company shall have a period of twenty-four (24) months from the date of notification to phase out all use. Any use by the Company of any of the Phase-Out Marks as permitted in this Section 6.6, is subject to its use of the Phase-Out Marks in a form and manner and with standards of quality consistent with that in effect for the Phase-Out Marks as of the Effective Date.
perturbation.changed_text: 6.6 With respect to any Trademarks notified to the Company in writing after the Effective Date that are used as of the Effective Date in the Company Field and are not (i) owned by any Company Entity, (ii) Arizona Assigned Trademarks, or (iii) Seller Licensed Trademarks (the "Phase-Out Marks") in each case (i)-(iii) the Company shall have a period of six (6) months from the date of notification to phase out all use. Any use by the Company of any of the Phase-Out Marks as permitted in this Section 6.6, is subject to its use of the Phase-Out Marks in a form and manner and with standards of quality consistent with that in effect for the Phase-Out Marks as of the Effective Date.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the phase-out period for trademarks from 24 months to 6 months introduces potential conflict with trademark law principles. A shorter phase-out may not provide sufficient time to deplete existing inventory, update marketing materials, and rebrand products, increasing the risk of consumer confusion and potential infringement claims if the company continues to use the phase-out marks beyond the legally permissible period.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Lanham Act (15 U.S.C. ยง 1114) - Trademark Infringement and Unfair Competition

perturbation.original_text: 9.3 Enforcement. As between the Parties, Arizona, with respect to the Arizona Licensed IP, and the Company or Buyer, with respect to the Company Licensed IP, shall have the right (but not the obligation) to elect to bring a Proceeding or enter into settlement discussions regarding, or otherwise seek to resolve, any infringement, misappropriation, or other violation, or allegations of invalidity or unenforceability, of the Licensed IP. In the event that Arizona declines to institute any Proceedings against third-party infringers or violators of any Arizona Licensed Patents, regarding activities that would fall within the Company Field if conducted by the Company, within forty-five (45) days after being notified or becoming aware of such infringing conduct, the Company or Buyer shall have the right to institute any Proceedings against such third-party infringers or violators. In the event that the Company or Buyer elects to institute such Proceedings, Arizona will reasonably cooperate with the Company or Buyer in such Proceedings, and the Company or Buyer shall reimburse Arizona for all reasonable costs and fees incurred by Arizona as a result of such cooperation. Such cooperation by Arizona will include joining such Proceeding as a party, if deemed necessary by the Company or Buyer. In the event that Arizona elects to bring a Proceeding against any alleged infringer of the Arizona Licensed Trademarks and seeks the cooperation of the Licensor of the Trademark License Agreement in such Proceeding, Arizona will take reasonable steps to assist the Company or Buyer in requesting the cooperation of the Licensor of the Trademark License Agreement, and pursuing an infringement claim against such alleged infringer. The Company or Buyer, as applicable, shall retain all benefits, recoveries, injunctions or other value derived from such Proceedings instituted by such Party.
perturbation.changed_text: 9.3 Enforcement. As between the Parties, Arizona, with respect to the Arizona Licensed IP, and the Company or Buyer, with respect to the Company Licensed IP, shall have the right (but not the obligation) to elect to bring a Proceeding or enter into settlement discussions regarding, or otherwise seek to resolve, any infringement, misappropriation, or other violation, or allegations of invalidity or unenforceability, of the Licensed IP. In the event that Arizona declines to institute any Proceedings against third-party infringers or violators of any Arizona Licensed Patents, regarding activities that would fall within the Company Field if conducted by the Company, within fifteen (15) days after being notified or becoming aware of such infringing conduct, the Company or Buyer shall have the right to institute any Proceedings against such third-party infringers or violators. In the event that the Company or Buyer elects to institute such Proceedings, Arizona will reasonably cooperate with the Company or Buyer in such Proceedings, and the Company or Buyer shall reimburse Arizona for all reasonable costs and fees incurred by Arizona as a result of such cooperation. Such cooperation by Arizona will include joining such Proceeding as a party, if deemed necessary by the Company or Buyer. In the event that Arizona elects to bring a Proceeding against any alleged infringer of the Arizona Licensed Trademarks and seeks the cooperation of the Licensor of the Trademark License Agreement in such Proceeding, Arizona will take reasonable steps to assist the Company or Buyer in requesting the cooperation of the Licensor of the Trademark License Agreement, and pursuing an infringement claim against such alleged infringer. The Company or Buyer, as applicable, shall retain all benefits, recoveries, injunctions or other value derived from such Proceedings instituted by such Party.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provided a 45-day window for Arizona to decide on legal proceedings against infringers. By shortening this period to 15 days, the modified text may not allow adequate time for a thorough investigation and assessment of the infringement claim, which is necessary under US patent and trademark laws to make informed decisions about litigation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: 35 U.S. Code ยง 287 - Limitation on damages; marking and notice
